articles.headline: Stock Bonuses at American Anger Pilots
articles.snippet: The combined $21 million in stock payouts to five top executives at American Airlines is looming large in labor talks with pilots.
articles.abstract: The combined $21 million in stock payouts to five top executives at American Airlines is looming large in labor talks with pilots.
articles.lead_paragraph: It may look like chicken feed in this era of mammoth executive pay packages, but a combined $21 million in stock payouts to five top executives at American Airlines is looming large in labor talks with pilots still angry about pay concessions made four years ago.

articles.headline: Stockman Is Charged With Fraud
articles.snippet: The former budget director for President Ronald Reagan was indicted on charges that he covered up the dire financial state at Collins & Aikman, the auto parts supplier he ran.
articles.abstract: The former budget director for President Ronald Reagan was indicted on charges that he covered up the dire financial state at Collins & Aikman, the auto parts supplier he ran.
articles.lead_paragraph: About a month before his company filed for bankruptcy protection, the chief executive of Collins & Aikman, a maker of vehicle instrument panels and floor mats, made a last-ditch attempt for a loan.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Heat Invades Cool Heights Over Arizona Desert
articles.snippet: The so-called sky islands, once green havens above the desert, are near collapse.
articles.abstract: The so-called sky islands, once green havens above the desert, are near collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUMMERHAVEN, Ariz. — High above the desert floor, this little alpine town has long served as a natural air-conditioned retreat for people in Tucson, one of the so-called sky islands of southern Arizona. When it is 105 degrees in the city, it is at least 20 degrees cooler up here near the 9,157-foot summit of Mount Lemmon.

articles.headline: Tough Days to Be a French Oilman
articles.snippet: Total’s aggressive practices may have led to an investigation of the company’s chief executive.
articles.abstract: Total’s aggressive practices may have led to an investigation of the company’s chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 26 — Christophe de Margerie, the new chief executive of Total, France’s largest corporation and one of the world’s big energy companies, was formally placed under investigation last week on suspicion of paying bribes to win a huge gas project in Iran.

articles.headline: Ulster Factions Agree to a Plan for Joint Rule
articles.snippet: Sinn Fein’s Gerry Adams and the Protestant leader, the Rev. Ian Paisley, held their first face-to-face talks on Monday.
articles.abstract: Sinn Fein’s Gerry Adams and the Protestant leader, the Rev. Ian Paisley, held their first face-to-face talks on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 26 — After years of hostility and recriminations, the leaders of Northern Ireland’s dominant rival groups, Gerry Adams of Sinn Fein and the Protestant leader, the Rev. Ian Paisley, held their first face-to-face talks on Monday and agreed to form a joint administration for the province on May 8.
articles.byline: By Eamon Quinn and Alan Cowell

articles.headline: AT&T Has Done the Deals. Now It Needs Results.
articles.snippet: Edward E. Whitacre Jr. has overseen a string of multibillion-dollar takeover deals, and now must compete through execution, not acquisition.
articles.abstract: Edward E. Whitacre Jr. has overseen a string of multibillion-dollar takeover deals, and now must compete through execution, not acquisition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the chairman and chief executive of AT&T, is captivating several hundred employees in an Atlanta auditorium with a pep talk about the rosy future of the world’s largest telephone company. His demeanor is commanding, cut with a practiced avuncular charm.

articles.headline: Citigroup to Cut at Least 10,000 in an Overhaul
articles.snippet: The move is part of a broad effort to cut costs and streamline the bank’s unwieldy global operations.
articles.abstract: The move is part of a broad effort to cut costs and streamline the bank’s unwieldy global operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup, the global banking giant, is stepping up its first major overhaul since it was forged by a merger nearly a decade ago.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Justices Hear Arguments About Pacts on Pricing
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court will determine whether retailers are permitted to discount a manufacturer’s product, even if the maker does not want the price to go below a certain level.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court will determine whether retailers are permitted to discount a manufacturer’s product, even if the maker does not want the price to go below a certain level.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 26  A 96-year-old rule that treats as an automatic antitrust violation any agreement between a manufacturer and its retailers to adhere to a minimum resale price is considered archaic and out of touch by the Bush administration and economists of the Chicago school.

articles.headline: Mindful of Past, Clinton Cultivates the Military
articles.snippet: Senator Clinton is striving to show voters that she is comfortable with military policy and culture.
articles.abstract: Senator Clinton is striving to show voters that she is comfortable with military policy and culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the early problems Bill Clinton faced as president, few stand out to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as more frustrating and avoidable than his rocky relationship with the military, her advisers say.
